user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_monotonic_sec_counter:
```c
time_t
MHD_monotonic_sec_counter (void)
{
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME
  struct timespec ts;

  if ( (_MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK != mono_clock_id) &&
       (0 == clock_gettime (mono_clock_id,
                            &ts)) )
    return ts.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME */
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_timespec_t cur_time;

    if (KERN_SUCCESS == clock_get_time (mono_clock_service,
                                        &cur_time))
      return cur_time.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
#if defined(_WIN32)
#if _WIN32_WINNT >= 0x0600
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (GetTickCount64 () - tick_start)) / 1000);
#else  /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
  if (0 != perf_freq)
  {
    LARGE_INTEGER perf_counter;

    QueryPerformanceCounter (&perf_counter);   /* never fail on XP and later */
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) perf_counter.QuadPart - perf_start)
                     / perf_freq);
  }
#endif /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
#endif /* _WIN32 */
#ifdef HAVE_GETHRTIME
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (gethrtime () - hrtime_start)) / 1000000000);
#endif /* HAVE_GETHRTIME */

  return time (NULL) - sys_clock_start;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 applies specifically to use of the <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) and ensuring they do not access beyond object bounds. The provided function contains no calls to any of the listed string-handling functions or other <string.h> APIs. The code only uses time-related APIs (clock_gettime, clock_get_time, GetTickCount64, QueryPerformanceCounter, gethrtime, time), integer casts and arithmetic, and passes addresses of fixed-sized timing structures (struct timespec, mach_timespec_t, LARGE_INTEGER) to OS APIs. There are no buffer copies, no pointer arithmetic operating on character buffers, and no uses of the standard string functions that could cause out-of-bounds accesses. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation under Rule 21.17.
